note.p: James J. Smylie was a businessman, Confederate officer, and Methodist minister in Mississippi in the nineteenth century.

Born on October 9, 1829, in Copiah County, Mississippi, Smylie was a successful businessman and farmer active in the Methodist church. In 1861, following the outbreak of the Civil War, he was appointed Quartermaster of the Third Mississippi Infantry Regiment, and labored to acquire and disperse supplies for Confederate forces over the next few years.

After the Civil War, Smylie worked as an insurance agent and became a Methodist preacher. He died on December 31, 1880. Smylie was married to Sarah Elizabeth Stovall and had at least five children. He is buried in Rose Hill Cemetery in Quitman County, Mississippi.

(FindaGrave; The Farmer’s Vindicator, Jackson, MS, May 14, 1875; “Letter from Secretary of War Judah P. Benjamin to Mississippi Governor John J. Pettus; October 31, 1861,” Civil War and Reconstruction Governors of Mississippi, mdah_75-940-04-32)

Charles Clarke Shackleford was an attorney, state political figure, and judge in Mississippi during the nineteenth century.

Born on September 15, 1813, in Kentucky, Shackleford moved to Mississippi in 1836, after receiving a law degree from Transylvania College. He became a successful attorney and plantation owner, acquiring several enslaved laborers. By the 1840s he entered state politics, serving in the Mississippi House of Representatives and participating in the several political conventions throughout the 1850s. After the Civil War, Shackleford gained prominence as judge over the Eleventh Judicial District in Mississippi. He died on June 22, 1878. Shackleford was married to Francis A. Irvin and had at least four children.

(Vicksburg Weekly Sentinel, Vicksburg, MS, February 22, 1851; The Yazoo Democrat, Yazoo City, MS, August 13, 1859; The Clarion-Ledger, Jackson, MS, July 3, 1878; Biographical and Historical Memoirs of Mississippi, Vol. II, 32; Daily Mississippi Pilot, Jackson, MS, October 13, 1875)

note.p: Albert Gallatin Brown was governor of Mississippi, a U.S. congressman and senator from Mississippi, and a member of the Confederate Senate. Born on May 31, 1813, in South Carolina, Brown moved with his family to Mississippi in 1823. Over the course of ten years, Brown’s family established a cotton plantation that contained 1,600 acres of land and 23 slaves. He attended Mississippi College and Jefferson College, and studied law to become a practicing attorney in 1834. A year later, he entered politics, winning a seat in Mississippi’s House of Representatives in 1835 and then serving in the U.S. House of Representatives from 1839 to 1841. He was a judge in Mississippi’s Circuit Superior Court from 1842 to 1843 and then, at the age of 31, won Mississippi’s gubernatorial election in 1843 as a Democrat. Brown was a staunch advocate of public education and successfully established the University of Mississippi, which opened in 1848.

Brown left the governor’s mansion in 1848 and returned to the U.S. House of Representatives. He served there until winning a seat in the U.S. Senate in 1854. He was an outspoken defender of slavery in Washington, D.C., in the latter half of the 1850s, even advocating the expansion of American slavery to Central America. When Mississippi seceded in 1861, following Abraham Lincoln’s election to the presidency, Brown resigned his seat in the Senate and returned to Mississippi to organize a militia company. He led his unit to Virginia, but was shortly afterwards elected to represent Mississippi in the Confederate Senate. He remained a member there until the end of the war.

Brown was among a small number of Confederate officials who foresaw the fall of the Confederacy in the wake of the battlefield defeats at Gettysburg and Vicksburg. He unsuccessfully recommended a negotiated settlement with the Union. When the war ended in 1865, Brown took a more reconciliatory stance to Reconstruction than many other former Confederates, recommending that the south accept emancipation. Despite having a political career during a controversial and dangerous period in American history, Brown was described as being among the most amicable and fair public figures, refusing to castigate or criticize his political opponents.

After the Civil War, Brown left public life. He practiced law in Mississippi for the next fifteen years. Brown was married twice during his life, first to Elizabeth Frances Thornton Taliaferro, who died less than a year after their wedding. His second wife was Roberta Eugenia Young. The couple had one child.
Brown died of a stroke on June 12, 1880, at home in Mississippi. He is buried in Greenwood Cemetery in Jackson, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave; National Governors Association; David Sansing, “Albert Gallatin Brown: Fourteenth Governor of Mississippi: 1844-1848,” Mississippi History Now)
Albert Gallatin Brown belonged to the following social groups:

person.persName: Barry, William T. S. (William Taylor Sullivan), 1821-1868

note.p: William Taylor Sullivan Barry served in the Mississippi legislature and the U.S. House of Representatives, before serving in the Provisional Congress of the Confederate States of America during the first two years of the Civil War.

Born on December 10, 1821, in Columbus, Mississippi, Barry attended Yale College, receiving a degree in 1841, and then studied law. He became a practicing attorney in 1844 and entered politics shortly afterwards. He won election to the Mississippi House of Representatives in 1848 and served until 1851. In 1852, he won a seat in the U.S. House of Representatives and served a single term there. Returning to state politics, he again entered the Mississippi legislature and became Speaker of the House in 1856.

In 1861, Barry was elected president of the Mississippi secession convention. When the state declared its separation from the Union and then joined the Confederacy, Barry was elected to represent Mississippi at the Confederate Provisional Congress. He held a seat there from 1861 to 1862, and then volunteered for military service. He helped raise the Thirty-Fifth Mississippi Infantry Regiment and served as an officer in the regiment during the Vicksburg Campaign. Captured there in July 1863, Barry violated the terms of his parole and returned to the field early to lead his regiment in the Atlanta Campaign. He saw heavy combat in 1864, sustaining wounds during the Battle of Allatoona in October 1864. Barry continued to lead troops in the field until captured near the end of the war at Fort Blakeley, Alabama.

After being released by federal officials at the end of the war, Barry returned to Columbus, Mississippi, and practiced law. He died on January 29, 1868. He was married to Sarah Fearn and had at least one child. Barry is buried Friendship Cemetery in Columbus, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave)
William Taylor Sullivan Barry belonged to the following social groups:
Alexander Mosby Clayton was a judge and political figure in Mississippi during the nineteenth century.

Born on January 15, 1801, in Campbell County, Virginia, Clayton studied law and became a practicing attorney in that state in 1823. He moved to Arkansas Territory in 1832 to accept an appointment from President Andrew Jackson as a judge in the territory’s superior court. Five years later, he relocated to Mississippi. Clayton was elected to Mississippi’s High Court of Errors and Appeals (the precursor to the state’s Supreme Court) in 1842 and served until 1852. During that same period in Mississippi, Clayton was appointed the first president of the University of Mississippi Board of Trustees, and served in that role until 1852. In 1853, Clayton received an appointment from President Franklin Pierce to be consul in Havana, Cuba. He served one year in that role, and then returned to Mississippi to practice law.

During the 1850s, Clayton became an outspoken proponent of secession in response to northern anti-slavery activities. He was a delegate to the Nashville Convention, a meeting of southern delegates to debate the political dispute over slavery in territories gained from the Mexican-American War, and promoted a hardline stance, including disunion, to protect slaveholding interests. Ten years later, in January 1861, at Mississippi's secession convention in the wake of Abraham Lincoln’s election to the president, Clayton again advocated secession, and wrote the state’s declaration of reasons for separating from the Union. He was then selected to represent the state in the Provisional Congress of the Confederate States during the spring of 1861. Following his short time in the Confederate Congress, Clayton served as a Confederate district court judge during the Civil War.

A year after the war ended, Clayton received an appointment as a circuit judge in Mississippi. He held that position for three years before being removed by federal officials in 1869, following ratification of the Fourteenth Amendment and its provision that prohibited previous U.S. officials who had supported the Confederacy from holding military or civil office. He returned to private law practice, as well as worked as director of the Mississippi Central Railroad.
Clayton died on September 30, 1889. He was married to Barbara Barker and had at least two children who survived to adulthood. He is buried in Hill Crest Cemetery in Holly Springs, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; Leslie H. Southwick, “Alexander Clayton [1801-1889] Judge,” Mississippi Encyclopedia)

note.p: Benjamin Grubb Humphreys was governor of Mississippi from 1865 to 1868, during the first three years of Reconstruction. Born on August 26, 1808, in Claiborne County, Mississippi, Humphreys spent many years in the north as a boy, attending school in New Jersey and then being appointed to the United States Military Academy at West Point, New York. Enrolled in the same class as Robert E. Lee, Humphreys was expelled shortly afterwards for his participation in the “Eggnog riot” (or “grog mutiny”)—an alcohol-fueled ruckus at West Point on the night of December 24-25, 1826, that resulted in the removal of twenty students.

Humphreys returned to Mississippi where he studied law and helped his father on the family plantation. He married Mary McLaughlin in 1832. The couple had two children before Mary died in 1835. He remarried in 1839 to Mildred Maury and had at least ten more children.

In the 1830s, Humphreys entered local politics as a Whig, serving as a state representative and then as a member of the Mississippi senate from 1839 to 1844. He purchased land to establish a cotton plantation in Sunflower County, Mississippi, in 1846, and helped establish the town of Itta Bena.

During the lead up to the Civil War, Humphreys opposed secession. However, after Mississippi declared its separation from the Union and joined the Confederate States of America, he volunteered for military service and was eventually elected colonel of the Twenty-first Mississippi Infantry. Humphreys and his regiment served within Brigadier General William Barksdale’s brigade in the eastern theater, notably seeing action at the Peach Orchard during the Battle of Gettysburg on July 2, 1863. Barksdale was killed during the battle, and Humphreys was promoted to brigadier general to take his place. He remained in command of the brigade until September 1864 when he was wounded at Berryville, Virginia. He spent the rest of the Civil War recuperating from his wounds.

Humphreys became active in the immediate postwar political scene in Mississippi. He won election for governor in October 1865 during Mississippi’s effort to earn readmission into the Union under President Andrew Johnson’s lenient Reconstruction plan. However, Humphreys was among the former southern leaders initially denied presidential pardon by Johnson. Although Johnson soon relented, sending a pardon to Humphreys, the Mississippi legislature’s passage of highly discriminatory laws (known as the Black Codes) against recently emancipated African Americans sparked a fierce backlash by Republicans in the United States Congress, who then refused to admit Mississippi back into the Union. Federal authorities instituted a stricter Reconstruction program, which included oversight by military officials. Humphreys remained governor, as Reconstruction did not disassemble Mississippi’s civil government. However, Humphreys did not enjoy the full authority of a traditional state executive. His white supremacist views and opposition to Black civil rights put him in frequent opposition to Republican Reconstruction goals. He won reelection in 1868, but soon afterwards was ejected from office by federal authorities when Radical Republicans took more direct control of Reconstruction.

Following his removal as governor in 1868, Humphreys left politics and began working in insurance in Jackson, Mississippi. He retired in 1877 and died in December 1882 and is buried in Wintergreen Cemetery at Port Gibson, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; David Sansing, “Benjamin Grubb Humphreys: Twenty-sixth Governor of Mississippi: 1865–1868,” Mississippi History Now; “Benjamin Grubb Humphreys,” HarpWeek)
Benjamin Grubb Humphreys belonged to the following social groups:

John Jones McRae was a lawyer and statesman from Mississippi who served in the Mississippi House of Representatives, the U.S. Senate, the U.S. House of Representatives, as the 21st Governor of Mississippi, and the Confederate Congress.

McRae was born on January 10, 1815 in Sneedsboro (present-day McFarlan), Anson County, North Carolina. At age two, his family moved to Winchester, Wayne County, Mississippi in 1817 and later to Pascagoula, Jackson County, Mississippi in 1827. He attended the University of Miami in Ohio, graduating in 1834. McRae returned to Mississippi to study law at Pearlington. He was admitted to the bar in 1835 and began practicing law in Paulding, Mississippi. In October 1835 he married Mary Annette McGuire, and the couple had three children together. He founded the newspaper Eastern Clarion in 1837.

McRae’s political career began when he was elected as a Democrat to the Mississippi House of Representatives in 1847, serving as Speaker of the House in 1850. He was appointed to the United States Senate from December 19, 1851 until March 17, 1852 to serve the remainder of Jefferson Davis’s unexpired term when he resigned to run for Governor of Mississippi.

In 1853 McRae was elected as the 21st Governor of Mississippi under the Democratic States’ Rights platform. He was reelected in 1855. During his time in the Governorship McRae’s administration oversaw the opening of the state’s first mental hospital and established an asylum for the deaf and speechless. He also oversaw the State’s levy program in the Delta and signed the Mississippi Code of 1857 into law. McRae was elected to the United States House of Representatives in 1858 following the death of Congressman John A. Quitman. He served in Congress until January 12, 1861, resigning his seat three days after Mississippi seceded from the Union. He was elected to the Confederate Congress and served from 1862 to 1864.

McRae was not involved in public affairs after the Civil War. His wife Mary died in 1866. In 1868 he sailed to Belize (present-day Belize City), British Honduras (Present-day Belize) to visit his brother. While there he died unexpectedly on May 31, 1868. He is buried at Lord Ridge Cemetery, Belize City, Belize.
(United States Congress, Biographical Directory of the United States Congress; Mississippi Department of Archives and History; NCpedia; FamilySearch; FindaGrave; Wikipedia)

note.p: Jehu Amaziah Orr was a representative of Mississippi in the Confederate States Congress during the Civil War.

Born on May 10, 1828, in Anderson County, South Carolina, he moved to Mississippi as a child. He graduated from Erskine College in South Carolina, before attending Princeton University in late 1840s. He left Princeton before graduation due to illness, but returned to earn a Master’s degree there in 1857. Orr became a prominent figure in Mississippi politics as a young man, being appointed as secretary to a Mississippi state convention on slavery in 1849, and later serving as secretary of the Mississippi Senate, a state representation, a district attorney, and then in 1861 being elected a delegate to Mississippi’s secession convention.

Once Mississippi joined the Confederacy, Orr won a seat representing Mississippi at the Confederate Provisional Congress in Montgomery, Alabama. In early 1862, he stepped away from politics to command the Thirty-First Mississippi Infantry Regiment. He led the unit through several battles, until 1864 when he returned to politics and took a seat in the Confederate House of Representatives, which he held until the end of the Civil War.

After the war Orr returned to practicing law. He served as judge of Mississippi’s Sixth Judicial District from 1869 to 1876, and then ran a very successful law firm, serving as the attorney for the Mobile & Ohio Railroad Company. He was married to Cornelia Ewing Van de Graaff and had four children. Late in his life, Orr became an outspoken supporter of women’s voting rights alongside his daughter Pauline Van de Graaff Orr, a notable suffragist. He was among the last surviving members of the Confederate Congress, and was widely praised in the early twentieth century for his more progressive views toward racial and social equality compared to his former Confederate colleagues.
Orr died in on March 9, 1921, at his daughter’s home in New York. He was 92 years old. He is buried in Friendship Cemetery in Columbus, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave; Jessica R. Mack, “Jehu A. Orr,” Princeton & Slavery; St. Louis Post-Dispatch, St. Louis, MO, April 24, 1910; The Columbus Dispatch, Columbus, MS, March 13, 1921)

note.p: Gilbreth Falls Neill was a Mississippi politician and Confederate officer during the Civil War.

Born in Tennessee on August 10, 1810, Neill moved to Carroll County, Mississippi, as a young man and became a successful attorney and planter. He served in the Mexican War and afterwards successfully ran for public office, serving in the Mississippi House of Representatives from 1850 to 1852 and in the Mississippi Senate from 1857 to 1862. In April 1862 he volunteered for military service, was commissioned colonel, and placed into command of the Thirtieth Mississippi Infantry Regiment. The unit saw heavy combat at the Battle of Murfreesboro, from December 31, 1862, to January 2, 1863.

Neill resigned his commission due to poor health in May 1863 and returned to Mississippi. He served as a tax collector for the rest of the war. He continued to be plagued with health problems, preventing his return to Mississippi politics during Reconstruction. He died on April 27, 1877. Neill was married three times, first to Amanda Malvina Hart in 1840, who passed away only a year after their marriage. Neill then married Caroline Judith Hart in 1845. She died in 1859. Neill married for a third, and final time, in 1864 to Helen Adele Humphries. He had at least nine children. Neill is buried in Evergreen Cemetery in North Carrollton, Mississippi.
(FindaGrave; National Park Service; The Clarion-Ledger, April 25, 1877)

note.p: Born on August 13, 1807 in Mississippi, Jeremiah S. Robinson was a farmer living in Carroll County, Mississippi in 1850. From 1854 to 1858, he was a Court Clerk in Bolivar County. During the Civil War, he was a Captain in the 1st Division, Mississippi militia, and after the war, he was appointed as the Commissioner tasked with selling the state's property invested in the Mississippi State Distillery and Salt Works.

Robinson was married to Addell Robinson, who preceded him in death in 1862. The pair had four children, none of whom lived to adulthood. Jeremiah S. Robinson died on November 23, 1879. He was buried in the Sidon Cemetery in Sidon, Leflore County, Mississippi.

(FindaGrave; U.S. Census Record for Carroll County, Mississippi, 1850; Vicksburg Whig, August 30, 1854; Vicksburg Daily Whig, January 16, 1858; Mississippi Free Trader, March 11, 1861; The Clarion Ledger, October 11, 1866)

William F. Dowd was a prominent Mississippi attorney who served as a Confederate officer during the Civil War.

Born at Society Hill, South Carolina, on December 31, 1820, Dowd moved as a child with his parents to Tennessee. He moved to Mississippi in 1841 and began to study law. He became a practicing attorney in 1846 and soon joined the firm of Coopwood, Herbert & Dowd in Aberdeen, Mississippi. His found tremendous success through is legal career, becoming one of the wealthiest attorneys in the state. Dowd’s income in 1854 was estimated to be $20,000—more nearly $700,000 in modern figures. His fame as an attorney and public speaker naturally led him to politics, and he became editor of a pro-Whig Party newspaper in Aberdeen in the 1850s.

Dowd strongly supported Mississippi’s right to secession, and when the Civil War broke out in 1861, he helped raise a regiment of volunteers, later accepted into Confederate service as the Twenty-fourth Mississippi Infantry Regiment. He was elected colonel in command of the unit and led it through numerous battles, including Corinth, Perryville, Lookout Mountain, and Missionary Ridge. He resigned from command late in the war due to health problems and accepted an appointment as a military judge in northern Alabama.

After the Civil War, Dowd returned to practicing law in Mississippi until he passed away on November 28, 1872, in Aberdeen. He was married to Ann W. Brown and had at least three children that survived to adulthood. Dowd is buried at Odd Fellows Rest Cemetery in Aberdeen, Mississippi.
(FindaGrave; Biographical and Historical Memoris of Mississippi, Vol. 1, 659)

note.p: Hezekiah William Foote was a Confederate officer and politician in Mississippi.

Born on December 17, 1813, in Chester County, South Carolina, Foote moved to Macon, Mississippi, in his youth. He studied law and became a practicing attorney, but also worked as a farmer raising cattle, a newspaper editor, a Chancery Clerk, and a district judge. He was a member of the Whig Party and unsuccessfully ran for the Mississippi House of Representatives in the mid-1850s.

When the Civil War broke out in 1861, Foote volunteered for military service. He was made a captain in the First Mississippi Cavalry Battalion, and later was promoted to colonel within the Mississippi state militia. Foote saw action at Belmont and Shiloh.

After the war, Foote again pursued political office. He was elected to the Mississippi House of Representatives and the Mississippi Senate. Through his various business pursuits (which included serving as president of the Farmers and Merchants Bank in Macon, Mississippi), as well as property he received through marriage, Foote became extremely wealthy. He owned at least four plantations, and helped found Vanderbilt University in Tennessee.

Foote died on January 29, 1899. He had been married four times, first to Lucinda Davis, who passed away in 1856. He then married Margy G. Foote (a cousin), who died in 1859. Foote then married Sybilla Antoinette Messinger, and was last married to Eleanor W. Curtiss. He had at least nine children. Foote is buried at Odd Fellows Cemetery in Macon, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave)

note.p: James Gordon was a Confederate officer and a United States Senator from Mississippi.

Born in Cotton Gin Port, Mississippi, on December 6, 1833, Gordon attended various schools in Mississippi and Alabama before graduating from the University of Mississippi in 1855. He worked as a newspaper writer and then served in the Mississippi House of Representatives in the late 1850s. During the Civil War, Gordon was commissioned as an officer in the Chickasaw Guards, attached to a Mississippi cavalry regiment known as the Jeff Davis Guards, and then was a lieutenant colonel in the Second Mississippi Cavalry Regiment.

In 1864, southern officials sent Gordon to Europe to lobby on behalf of the Confederacy. He was captured by Union forces in Wilmington, North Carolina, in January 1865, but successfully escaped and traveled to Canada. He was there when the war ended, and returned to the United States to face charges of conspiring in the death of Abraham Lincoln due to evidence that he had met with John Wilkes Booth, Lincoln’s assassin, while in Canada. Gordon admitted that while in Montreal he had discussed plans with Booth to kidnap the president, but denied having any knowledge of the assassination. Federal officials eventually dropped their charges against Gordon.

Gordon held various Mississippi public offices in the late nineteenth century, including serving in the state House of Representatives. Most notably, in 1909, at the age of 76, he received an appointment to fill a vacancy in the U.S. Senate following the death of Mississippi senator Anselm J. McLaurin. He was in the Senate for only eight weeks, when the Mississippi legislature elected LeRoy Percy to take the seat.

Gordon died on November 28, 1912. He was married twice, first to Carolina Virginia Wiley, who passed away in 1903. He then married Ella Narcissa Neilson in 1904. Gordon had at least two children who survived to adulthood.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave; Biographical Directory of the United States Congress, 1774-Present)

note.p: Jones S. Hamilton was a Confederate officer who later became a wealthy railroad investor and businessman in Mississippi.

Born on April 19, 1833, in Wilkinson County, Mississippi, Hamilton was educated in Mississippi and then graduated from Centenary College in Louisiana. He served as sheriff of Wilkinson County during the late 1850s but resigned the position to volunteer for Confederate military service when the Civil War broke out in 1861. He served in a Mississippi unit in the Army of Northern Virginia, eventually attaining the rank of lieutenant colonel. After the war, Hamilton settled in Jackson, Mississippi, and held various public positions, including the deputy state auditor, adjutant general in the Mississippi militia, and a state senator. Most notably, he gained fame and wealth through railroad projects and commercial enterprises. Hamilton was credited with driving much of the infrastructure and railroad development in southern Mississippi. He also became strongly associated with the convict leasing program, where his companies paid the state to use prisoners from Mississippi’s penitentiary as laborers on public works and construction projects. By the late nineteenth century, Hamilton was a millionaire.

Hamilton’s financial success and business methods drew criticism from some, and in the 1880s he became embroiled in a dispute with a newspaper editor named Roderick Gambrell. The feud led to a duel in which Hamilton killed Gambrell. He was acquitted, but the incident underscored the controversy surrounding him and contributed to perceptions like that written by the Vicksburg American, who noted that “no man connected with public affairs of Mississippi . . . had led a more eventful, and to a certain extent, checkered, career than Jones S. Hamilton.”

Hamilton died on January 21, 1907. He had been married twice, first to Carolina Augusta Stewart in 1856, with whom he had two children. She died in 1861 and he later married Fannie Buck in 1877 and had five additional children. Hamilton is buried in Greenwood Cemetery in Jackson, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave; The Vicksburg American, Vicksburg, MS, January 21, 1907; Jackson Daily News, Jackson, MS, January 21, 1907)

note.p: Thomas Walton Harris was an attorney and Confederate officer from Mississippi.

Born on April 15, 1825, in Walton County, Georgia, he moved to Mississippi in his youth and became an attorney. Harris was active in public and political activities during the 1850s, including being elected an officer in the Mississippi militia and rising to commandant of the Division of Mississippi Volunteers in 1860. He served as a delegate to Democratic Party conventions in Mississippi and took a “states rights” position, which adopted a harder line position, and supported secessionist sentiments, during the political dispute over slavery in the United States during the 1850s.

When the Civil War broke out in 1861, Harris volunteered for Confederate service. He served as an officer in the Ninth Mississippi Infantry Regiment, and then was commissioned a lieutenant colonel in the Third Battalion Mississippi Cavalry. He lost an arm due to combat during the war.

After the Civil War, Harris returned to his law practice. He made frequent speeches at political and social gatherings, and was briefly considered a candidate for attorney general and for Congress in the Greenback Party in the 1870s and 1880s. In the 1880s he formed a law partnership with former Confederate general James Ronald Chalmers in Tennessee. Harris died on April 28, 1890, at the age of 65. He was married twice, first to Elizabeth Mason. She passed away in 1853. He later married Susan Watson. Harris had at least three children. He is buried in Hill Crest Cemetery in Holly Springs, Mississippi.

(FindaGrave; 1850 U.S. Census for Columbus Ward 3, Lowndes County, Mississippi, Roll 376, page 125a; The Weekly Mississippian, Jackson, MS, August 3, 1851, and April 22, 1853; Southern Standard, Columbus, MS, June 21, 1851; The Weekly Democrat, Natchez, MS, August 4, 1880; The Clarion-Ledger, Jackson, MS, June 13, 1877, and April 2, 1879; The Vicksburg Post, Vicksburg, MS, December 17, 1886; “3rd Battalion, Mississippi Cavalry [Aschraft’s],” FamilySearch; Historical Data Systems, Inc., American Civil War Research Database, Ancestry.com)

Cameron "Howell" Hinds was a planter, Mississippi state Representative, and a 1st Lieutenant in the Confederate Army.

Born in 1808 in Jefferson County, Mississippi, Hinds was a planter and enslaver living in Jefferson County, Mississippi by 1836, and in 1852, he served a term as state Representative for Jefferson County. During the Civil War, he served as a First Lieutenant in the Jefferson Flying Artillery Battery, serving the Confederate Army. In 1863, during the Gettysburg campaign, he was wounded in Mechanicsburg, Pennsylvania.

After the Civil War, Hinds moved to Greenville, Mississippi. Hinds was married to Mary Ann (Coleman) Hinds, with whom he had at least five children, including two sons who lived to adulthood. In an attempt to stop a pistol duel between two friends, Hinds died on May 13, 1868 in Greenville, Mississippi. He was buried in the Greenville Cemetery.

(FindaGrave; U.S. Census Record for Jefferson County, Mississippi, 1850; U.S. Census Record for Jefferson County, Mississippi, 1860; The Mississippi Free Trader, December 13, 1836; Howell Hinds to Mississippi Governor Benjamin G. Humphries, July 24, 1866, Civil War & Reconstruction Governors of Mississippi, mdah_779-963-09-15)

note.p: William Washington Humphries was a Confederate officer, attorney, and politician from Mississippi during the nineteenth century.

Born on June 20, 1841, in Columbus, Mississippi, Humphries graduated from the University of North Carolina in 1858 and received a degree from Lebanon Law School in 1860. He briefly practiced law in Columbus before the Civil War broke out in 1861.

Humphries volunteered for military service and was commissioned a lieutenant in the Thirty-fifth Mississippi Infantry Regiment in 1862. He finished the war at the rank of captain and returned to Columbus to practice law. He served in the Mississippi Senate from 1880 to 1884.

He died on February 6, 1904, at the age of 62, after months of failing health and a sudden illness. He was married twice, first to Mary Thomas Jones, who passed away in 1885. He then married Fannie Randall Moore. Humphries had at least four children that survived to adulthood. He is buried in Friendship Cemetery in Columbus, Mississippi.
(FindaGrave; The Columbus Weekly Dispatch, Columbus, MS, February 11, 1904)

Jeptha Vining Harris was a brigadier general in the Mississippi militia during the Civil War.

Born on December 1, 1816, in Elbert County, Georgia, Harris graduated from the University of Georgia in 1836 and moved to Mississippi in 1840. He became a wealthy planter, owning several slaves, in Lowndes County. During the 1850s, Harris became involved in state politics, winning election to the Mississippi Senate in 1858.

He held his seat until 1861 and then volunteered for military service during the first year of the Civil War. He served as a brigadier general from 1862 to 1863, leading state troops during the Vicksburg Campaign. Harris and his brigade were captured by Ulysses S. Grant’s army at Vicksburg in July 1863. He was formally exchanged as a prisoner a few weeks later and mustered out of the military. Harris remained a civilian for a year and then returned to the military in 1864, receiving a commission as a colonel in charge of forces at Macon, Mississippi. He remained there until the end of the Civil War in 1865.

After the Civil War, Harris returned to his land in Lowndes County, Mississippi. He died there on November 21, 1899. Harris was married to Mary Oliver Banks and had three children who survived to adulthood. He is buried in Friendship Cemetery in Columbus, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave)
Jeptha V. Harris belonged to the following social groups:
Hampton L. Jarnigan was an attorney, judge, and state congressman in Mississippi.

Born in Tennessee on February 22, 1812, Jarnigan moved to Macon, Mississippi, in 1838 and became a successful attorney. He came to prominence after the Civil War, testifying before Congress about Ku Klux Klan activities against African Americans in Mississippi, and then winning elections to the Mississippi House of Representatives and the Mississippi Senate.

Jarnigan died on January 20, 1886. He was married twice, first to Rebecca B. McCaskill who died in 1867. He then married Abbie L. Perkins in 1869. Jarnigan had at least three children. He is buried in Odd Fellows Cemetery in Macon, Mississippi.

(Wikipedia; FindaGrave; “Jarnigan-Scales House,” MDAH Historic Resources Inventory Fact Sheet; United States Congress Select Committee on the Condition of Affairs in the Late Insurrectionary States, “Report of and Testimony, Volume 11,” 513)
Hampton L. Jarnigan belonged to the following social groups:

However, John Jones belonged to the following social groups:
Tullius Cicero Tupper was a general in the Mississippi militia during the Civil War.

Born in Barnard, Vermont, on February 9, 1809, Tupper was educated in the north and graduated from the University of Vermont before moving to Canton, Mississippi. He practiced law in Mississippi and became involved in newspaper publishing, running the Canton Herald in the 1830s. He became highly respected over the next two decades, serving as an advisor to Mississippi governor John J. Pettus during the secession crisis in 1860 and 1861.

In 1862, Tupper received a commission as major general in the Mississippi militia, tasked with organizing and improving state forces at a time when most able-bodied Mississippi men who wanted to volunteer for military service were serving in the Confederate army. Tupper clashed with Pettus over the use of the state militia. He preferred to allow militia troops to return home following training and only be called into service during emergency situations. The governor wished to keep the militia units on active duty and in garrison. Additionally, Tupper resisted efforts by Confederate officials to control state military forces. In 1863, Tupper resigned his commission and spent the rest of the war at home.
Tupper died on August 14, 1866. He was married to Mary Harding Drane and had five children. He is buried in Canton City Cemetery, Canton, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave)
T. C. Tupper belonged to the following social groups:
James Alexander Ventress was an attorney and politician in Mississippi during the nineteenth century.

Born on February 12, 1805, in Clarksville, Tennessee, Ventress moved to Mississippi as a child with his family. He was well educated, attending schools in Mississippi, Louisiana, and Europe. Initially interested in science, Ventress eventually studied law and became a practicing attorney. He became involved in politics in the 1830s and served in the Mississippi legislature for several years, including a period of time as the state’s Speaker of the House.
Ventress died on June 26, 1867. He was married to Charlotte Pynchon and had at least three children. He is buried in a family cemetery in Wilkinson, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave)

note.p: Absolom Madden West was a Confederate general, a Mississippi politician, railroad executive, and vice presidential candidate. Born in Alabama in 1818, West moved to Mississippi around 1837 to establish a plantation with property he acquired from federal land grants. He entered Mississippi state politics as a Whig and won a seat in the Mississippi Senate in 1847. He married Caroline O. Glover in the 1840s and the couple had four surviving children, born between 1849 and 1862.

In 1853, he took an office job with the new Mississippi Central Railroad, gaining experience not only in railroad development but corporate and logistical operations. As a Whig, West originally opposed secession. However, after Mississippi left the Union in 1861, during the secession crisis that split the country following Abraham Lincon’s election to president in November 1860, West offered his loyalty and services to the state. He was promoted a brigadier general in the Mississippi state militia, and helped raised a regiment of volunteers. Recognizing his skill and experience in administrative and logistical work, state officials appointed him to several different managerial roles, such as quartermaster general, paymaster general, and commissary general of the militia. He made recommendations to the state legislature to improve the accounting of funds, and was the only state officer to have his accounting books in order and submitted at the end of the war.

West took the role of president over the Mississippi Central Railroad around 1864. He remained in that position until around the end of the war, then returned to state politics—again serving in the Mississippi Senate—after the Illinois Central purchased the Mississippi Central. West was elected to the U.S. House of Representatives during the early effort by the Mississippi government in 1865 to earn readmission to the Union under President Andrew Johnson’s lenient Reconstruction plan. However, he was among the Mississippi delegation refused seats in Congress when Republicans in Washington, D.C., objected to Mississippi’s “Black Codes”—a series of highly discriminatory laws passed in the summer of 1865 to restrict the civil rights of African Americans.

West became involved in labor rights during Reconstruction, helping form a branch of the National Labor Union. Reentering the Mississippi Senate in the early 1870s, around 1876 he broke away from the Democratic Party and joined the emerging “Greenback Party”—an independent, anti-monopoly political party. It united many state-level politicians in the north and the south on economic matters, namely the expansion of paper currency believed to help farmers and small businesses. Attesting to the party’s ability to bring former enemies together, the party’s national convention in 1884 nominated former Union general Benjamin Butler (who had been despised within the Confederacy during his occupation of New Orleans during the Civil War) for its presidential candidate and the former Confederate militia general West as vice president. The party polled only a 1.7% of the popular vote in 1884.
West’s wife Caroline died in 1889 after a long bout of poor health. He died five years later, in 1894. The couple is buried in Hill Crest Cemetery in Holly Springs, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave)
Absalom Madden West belonged to the following social groups:
Henry B. Whitfield was a district attorney in Mississippi and editor of the Columbus Press after the Civil War.

Born in Alabama, Whitfield moved to Lowndes County, Mississippi, as a child. His father was James Whitfield, eighteenth governor of Mississippi. Henry Whitfield graduated from the University of Alabama and went into legal practice. He was an officer during the Civil War, reaching the rank of major.

After the war, Whitfield served as a district attorney for the Northern District of Mississippi and edited the Columbus Press in Columbus, Mississippi. He moved to Vicksburg in 1878 and operated a law firm with J. S. Morris. Whitfield died on September 30, 1883. He was married to Mary Montgomery.
(The Vicksburg Herald, Vicksburg, MS, January 12, 1872; The Weekly Mississippi Pilot, Jackson, MS, January 30, 1875; The Vicksburg Post, Vicksburg, MS, October 8, 1883)
Henry B. Whitfield belonged to the following social groups:
Richard Winter was a Mississippi banker and general in the state militia.

Born around 1821, Winter was a successful businessman and banker in Canton, Mississippi, by the 1850s. He was active in the state militia, temporarily serving as a major general in the state before the Civil War. In 1862, during the Civil War, Winter was elected brigadier general in command of the Second Brigade of the Mississippi state troops, comprising of militiamen from the counties of Yallobusha, Carroll, Calhoun, Choctaw, Holmes, Attala, Tallahatchie, Madison, Leake, Scott, Hinds, Rankin, Copiah, and Simpson. Besides his banking and militia duty, Winter was the editor of the American Citizen newspaper in Canton in 1864. After the Civil War, Winter returned to his business and finance work in Canton.
He died on July 28, 1870.
(The Weekly Mississippian, Jackson, MS, February 26, 1862, and March 5, 1862; The Clarion, Jackson, MS, July 28, 1870)
Richard Winter belonged to the following social groups:
Andrew Johnson was vice president under Abraham Lincoln during the Civil War and served as president, following Lincoln’s assassination, during the first three years of Reconstruction.

Born on December 29, 1808, in Raleigh, North Carolina, Johnson came from a poor family and was sent by his parents to apprentice in a tailor’s shop. Gaining a basic education from his coworkers and customers, Johnson eventually ran away from Raleigh before his apprenticeship obligation was completed and lived in Alabama and Tennessee. He established a successful tailor shop in Greeneville, Tennessee, earning enough money to purchase property and improve his education. He also began purchasing slaves, ultimately owning ten enslaved people before the Civil War.

Johnson became interested in politics in Tennessee and developed great skill as a stump speaker. He was elected mayor of Greeneville in 1834 and then won a seat in the Tennessee House of Representatives. Initially a Whig, Johnson joined the Democratic Party and gained strong party support. He improved his political standing by serving in the Tennessee militia, rising to the rank of colonel. In the early 1840s, he won election to the United States House of Representatives, serving in that body until 1853, when he became governor of Tennessee. He served two terms and then successfully ran for the United States Senate in 1856.

During the secession crisis and the outbreak of the Civil War in 1861, Johnson remained loyal to the Union. He faced harsh criticism from other Tennesseans, and was the only member of a seceded state to stay in the Senate. He was unable to return home during Congressional recesses during the war. In 1862, when his term as senator ended, Lincoln appointed Johnson military governor of Tennessee. He accepted the position and the rank of brigadier general, but faced retribution from Confederates in Tennessee who confiscated his land and property. As the war progressed, Johnson increasingly supported Republican efforts against slavery, including the Emancipation Proclamation.
During the 1864 presidential campaign, Lincoln selected Johnson as his vice presidential candidate to draw in southern Unionist and War Democrat support. They won the election, but Lincoln was assassinated in April 1865, only a few weeks after the inauguration, leaving Johnson to assume the presidency. Taking the executive office in the final days of the Civil War, Johnson began to enact his vision of Reconstruction of the southern states. He advocated for a rapid restoration of the Union and offered amnesty to most former Confederates. Johnson made exceptions for higher ranking Confederate officials, and required them to personally petition for pardons. He was less supportive of former slaves, and began to draw criticism from Republicans. In late 1865, states like Mississippi established highly restrictive laws, nicknamed Black Codes, against African Americans, drawing the ire of many northern Republicans. When Radical Republicans passed legislation designed to protect the rights of freed people, Johnson vetoed it, causing an even greater split between Congress and the president.

By 1866, Johnson’s popularity in the north had dropped significantly. Radical Republicans won electoral victories and in 1867 implemented stricter Reconstruction policies, placing the former Confederate states under military rule. When Johnson dismissed Secretary of War Edwin M. Stanton over policy disagreements, Republicans in Congress impeached him. He barely survived conviction in the United States Senate in 1868, but his political influence had essentially ended. The Republican Party chose Civil War hero Ulysses S. Grant as its next presidential candidate, and Johnson returned to Tennessee when his term ended in 1869.

Although unpopular in the north, Johnson was welcomed home in Tennessee by residents who appreciated his political battle against Radical Republicans in Washington, D.C. He won an election to the United States Senate in 1875, but served only a few weeks before dying of a stroke on July 31, 1875. He was married to Eliza McCardle and had five children. Johnson is buried in Greeneville, Tennessee.
(Wikipedia; The White House; FindaGrave)
Andrew Johnson belonged to the following social groups:
Charles Bingley Ames was an attorney and judge in Mississippi during the nineteenth century.

Born on October 1, 1812, in Amesville, Ohio, Ames moved to Mississippi in the 1830s, and purchased land in Noxubee County in 1841. He studied law and became a practicing attorney in the 1840s. By the early 1850s, Ames was active in state politics. In particular, he associated with Unionists during rising tensions over the Compromise of 1850 and the debate over the expansion of slavery in territories gained from the Mexican-American War. During the Civil War, Ames served as a tax collector in Mississippi.

When the war ended, he quickly took the oath of allegiance and continued to be a public figure. During the course of his lifetime, Ames served as a deputy sheriff and mayor of Macon, and was a probate judge. He died on August 3, 1888. Ames was married to Sarah Jane Longstreet, the sister of Confederate general James Longstreet. The couple had at least three children that survived to adulthood. Ames is buried in Odd Fellows Cemetery in Macon, Mississippi.

(FindaGrave; U.S. General Land Office Records, 1776-2015, Ancestry.com; “Charles Bingley Ames (1812-1888),” WikiTree; Flag of the Union, Jackson, MS, November 22, 1850; Macon Beacon, Macon, MS, November, 4, 1863)

note.p: James L. Alcorn served as governor and then U.S. senator for Mississippi in the 1870s.

Born November 4, 1816, in Illinois Territory, Alcorn spent much of his young adulthood in Kentucky. After attending Cumberland College in Princeton, Kentucky, Alcorn was deputy sheriff of Livingston County, Kentucky, and then entered legal practice in the state in the 1830s. He served a short stint in the Kentucky House of Representatives in the early 1840s and then relocated to Mississippi, where he practiced law in Coahoma County. Financial success as an attorney enabled Alcorn to buy land and establish Mound Place Plantation in the Mississippi Delta region. By 1860, Alcorn owned nearly one hundred slaves; his land holdings alone were valued at approximately $9.5 million in today’s currency. Alcorn married Mary C. Stewart of Kentucky in 1839. The couple had five children before Mary passed away in 1849. Alcorn married Amelia Walton Glover of Alabama in 1850. He fathered three children with his second wife.

Alcorn was a Unionist during the 1850s. He served as a delegate to a special Mississippi convention to debate the south’s response to the Compromise of 1850—legislation passed in the U.S. Congress designed to settle a fierce dispute over the fate of slavery in territories gained by the United States from Mexico. He warned that secession would lead to war, with federal soldiers invading the south, liberating slaves, and a destroying southern society. Alcorn and other Unionists carried the day during the 1851 convention.

During the 1850s, Alcorn served in the Mississippi House of Representatives and Senate as a Whig. He led a legislative effort to establish levees to reduce flooding in the Delta region, and was elected the first president of the levee board. As his standing in Mississippi politics increased, he ran for election to U.S. Congress in 1856 but lost. Whigs in Mississippi subsequently considered him for a gubernatorial run in 1857, but Alcorn turned it down.

During the secession crisis following Abraham Lincoln’s election to the U.S. presidency in 1860, Alcorn initially maintained his Unionist leanings. However, when Mississippi issued its ordnance of secession, Alcorn pledged his loyalty to the state and volunteered for military service in Mississippi. He received an appointment as brigadier general for the state militia in 1861, but his military advancement was hindered by powerful political rivals. Alcorn led a brigade of three Mississippi militia regiments into the field in October 1861. His brigade spent three months Kentucky—experiencing miserable weather and mud, but no combat—before disbanding in January 1862 when their enlistments expired.

Alcorn returned home from Kentucky embittered and embroiled in disputes with his personal and political rivals. Although he backed Mississippi following secession, Alcorn was not particularly committed to the Confederate cause. After federal soldiers entered Mississippi in 1862, his plantation was among those raided. However, Alcorn established contacts within the Union army and began trading cotton with federal authorities against Confederate policy. As a result, his wealth grew and his plantation was spared the same level of destruction meted out to notable secessionists.

Alcorn reentered Mississippi politics immediately upon the defeat of the Confederacy. He was elected to the U.S. Senate in 1865 by the postwar Mississippi government’s effort to earn readmission into the Union under President Andrew Johnson’s lenient Reconstruction plan. However, the Mississippi legislature passed a series of highly discriminatory laws (known as the Black Codes) against recently emancipated African Americans, prompting Republicans in the United States Congress to refuse Mississippi back into the Union. As a result, Alcorn was denied his seat in the Senate.

Alcorn became a leading member of the Republican Party in Mississippi as Reconstruction developed. He embraced Black civil rights, including African American suffrage. Although born in the north, his long residency in, and service to, Mississippi before and during the Civil War made him a “scalawag” (white southerner who joined the Republican Party) to conservative whites in the south. Nevertheless, he gained enough political support to win the Republican nomination for governor and then the gubernatorial election in 1869 as Mississippi reentered the Union. He entered office in 1870 and oversaw the development of a state public education system, the creation of a land-grant college for African Americans (named Alcorn University in his honor), and pro-business acts to improve economic development in the state.

Alcorn resigned as governor in 1871 to take a seat in the U.S. Senate for Mississippi. Though still a Republican, Alcorn represented a more conservative side of the party. Though supporting Black civil rights, he resisted some federal intervention in Mississippi affairs, and generally held white supremacist views. This put him in opposition to the other senator from Mississippi, Adelbert Ames, a former Union general who had served as a military governor in Reconstruction Mississippi and led the more radical faction of Republicans in Mississippi that pushed total racial equality. Alcorn and Ames ran against each other for governor of Mississippi in 1873. Ames won by carrying most African American votes.

Alcorn left the U.S. Senate in 1877 and returned to Mississippi. He did not take part in most state political matters, but did stay active in the levee system and governing. In 1890, he was selected to be a delegate to the Mississippi constitutional convention. He was among the delegates the supported new restrictions against Black Mississippi rights. Alcorn died on December 19, 1894. He is buried in Friars Point, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; Timothy B. Smith, Mississippi in the Civil War, 134-135; David Sansing, “James Lusk Alcorn: Twenty-eighth Governor of Mississippi: March 180 to November 1871,” Mississippi History Now)
James Lusk Alcorn belonged to the following social groups:
Jefferson B. Allgood was sheriff of Noxubee County, Mississippi, and a U.S. Postmaster after the Civil War.

Born on December 5, 1818, in Laurens, South Carolina, Allgood moved to Alabama as a young man. By 1850 he was a planter who owned more than a dozen slaves. Allgood moved to Mississippi in the early 1850s and remained there during the Civil War. He reportedly worked as a slave dealer.

Following the war, he worked as a cotton factor and commission merchant with partners in Mississippi and Alabama while becoming involved in Republican Party politics. He was elected sheriff of Noxubee County, Mississippi, in the 1870s. He received an appointment as U.S. Postmaster in Macon, Mississippi, in 1881. Allgood died on February 21, 1885. He was married to Darthula C. Jones and had at least five children, only one of whom survived to adulthood.

(1850 U.S. Federal Census [Alabama] – Slave Schedules; The Livingston Journal, Livingston, AL, January 5, 1867; The Clarion-Ledger, Jackson, MS, October 17, 1877; The Clarion, Jackson, MS, June 2, 1881; FindaGrave for “Darthula G. Jones Allgood”; Warren Wilkinson and Steven E. Woodworth, A Scythe of Fire, 22)
Jefferson B. Allgood belonged to the following social groups:
Eli Abbott was a politician and planter in northeast Mississippi.

Born on July 6, 1801 in Georgia, Abbott served as a captain in the Seminole War in Florida (1835-1842). After the war, he lived in Columbus, Lowdnes County, Mississippi, where he was a planter and enslaver of at least thirty-three men, women, and children. From 1838 to 1839, he was the city mayor, and from 1842 to 1843, he served as the sheriff. In 1849, he donated land for the First Christian Church in Columbus, Mississippi, and in 1853, he purchased land in Chickasaw County and was elected as a state Representative.
During the Civil War Abbott joined the Mississippi militia and served as the captain of Abbott's Company, Mississippi Cavalry for Chickasaw County.
After the war, Abbott joined the board of the Mobile and Ohio Railroad, and he moved to Egypt, Mississippi by 1870. He was working as a farmer.

Abbott was married to Clarissa "Clara" (Tapley) Abbott. The pair had two sons who lived to adulthood, but they also took in at least two nephews and possibly other orphaned children. Eli Abbott and his wife Clara died in 1879. They were buried in the Abbott Family Cemetery in Egypt, Chickasaw County, Mississippi.

(FindaGrave; Southern Argus, November 6, 1838; Columbus Democrat, June 8, 1839; The Primitive Republican, April 27, 1843; The Weekly Mississippian, June 22, 1843; The Weekly Mississippian, November 25, 1853; The Clarion Ledger, April 26, 1866; 1840 United States Federal Census, Lowdnes County, Mississippi; U.S. Census Record for Lowdnes County, 1850; U.S., Civil War Soldiers, 1861-1865 ; U.S. Census Record for Chickasaw County, Mississippi, 1870)
Eli Abbott belonged to the following social groups:

David N. Barrows was mayor of Jackson, Mississippi, in the 1860s. Born on August 27, 1816, in Wareham, Massachusetts, Barrows moved to Mississippi in 1835 and pursued various business ventures, finding success as an insurance agent. He was elected mayor of Jackson around 1863, during the Civil War, serving until 1867. He was married twice, first to Eleanor Langley. She died in 1849, and Barrows married Carrie E. Moseley in 1854. He had at least four children. Barrows died on July 18, 1895, and is buried in Greenwood Cemetery in Jackson, Mississippi.
(FindaGrave; The Democratic-Herald, Charleston, MS, July 25, 1895)

note.p: Charles Baskerville was a Confederate officer from Mississippi during the Civil War. Born in Virginia in 1821, Baskerville moved to Mississippi in the 1850s. He was a successful businessman in Columbus on the eve of the Civil War, and when hostilities broke out in 1861, he helped raise a cavalry battalion in Mississippi, variously known as the Second Battalion, the Fourth Battalion, and the Pope Walker Battalion. He served as an officer of the battalion, rising to the rank of lieutenant colonel. Baskerville led cavalry troops through many engagements in the Mississippi and Tennessee area.

He survived the war and returned to Mississippi, passing away on June 23, 1890. He was married twice, first to Margaret Haynes Freear, who died in 1853. He then married Jane Coleman. Baskerville had at least five children. He is buried in Friendship Cemetery in Columbus, Mississippi.

(1850 U.S. Census for Regiment 98, Mecklenburg, Virginia; 1860 U.S. Census for Columbus, Mississippi; Historical Data Systems, cop., U.S. Civil War Soldier Records and Profiles 1861-1865; FindaGrave; Dunbar Rowland, The Official and Statistical Register of the State of Mississippi, 1908, 799-801)

John W. Balfour was a Confederate officer from Mississippi during the Civil War.

Born in 1828 in Madison County, Mississippi, Balfour’s family were wealthy land owners and related by marriage to Jefferson Davis (U.S. senator, U.S. secretary of war, and then president of the Confederacy). Balfour was well educated and graduated from Oakland College.

During the Civil War he raised a state militia unit, nicknamed the “Beauregard Rifles” and was later appointed lieutenant colonel of the Sixth Mississippi Battalion. Balfour moved to different military units during the war, variously serving as a major in the Eighteen Mississippi Infantry Regiment and as a lieutenant colonel in the Thirty-first Mississippi Infantry Regiment. He was then commissioned as a colonel and authorized to raise the Forty-ninth Mississippi Infantry Regiment, but the unit was not formally organized. Balfour participated in several battles, most notably during the Vicksburg Campaign in 1863.
He died on April 19, 1903. He was married to Mary C. Humphreys.
(Jefferson Davis, The Papers of Jefferson Davis, ed. Lynda Lassell Crist, 641; National Park Service; Natchez Democrat, Natchez, MS, April 19, 1903)
John AW. Balfour belonged to the following social groups:

Charles Henry Manship served as mayor and as postmaster of Jackson, Mississippi, during the nineteenth century. Born on July 31, 1812, in Talbot County, Maryland, Manship moved to Mississippi in 1836. He soon became active in local affairs in Jackson, helping establish a fire department. Manship served as mayor of Jackson in 1862 and 1863, and later was postmaster. He was married to Adaline Daley and had at least fourteen children. He died on June 21, 1895, and is buried in Greenwood Cemetery in Jackson, Mississippi.
(The Times-Picayune, New Orleans, LA, June 22, 1895; FindaGrave; Clarion-Ledger, Jackson, MS, June 24, 1895)

William McWillie was governor of Mississippi in the late 1850s.

Born in Kershaw County, South Carolina on November 17, 1795, McWillie was educated at South Carolina College and became a practicing attorney in 1818. He entered politics in South Carolina in the 1830s, winning seats first in the state House of Representatives and then the South Carolina Senate. In 1845, he moved to Mississippi and lived on a large plantation. He immediately became active in the Mississippi political scene as a Democrat and advocate for state’s rights. Within four years of moving to Mississippi, McWillie won an election to the U.S. House of Representatives. He served in Congress from 1849 to 1851, but lost reelection to a Unionist candidate.

McWillie remained active in Mississippi politics and in 1857 won the gubernatorial election. As governor, he advocated for public schools and railroad development. He remained an ardent defender of slavery, and in 1859 he called upon a strengthening of the Mississippi militia in response to fears of slave revolts, following John Brown’s abolitionist raid on Harper’s Ferry in Virginia.

McWillie departed the governor’s office in 1859 and sought no other public position. He supported Mississippi’s secession in 1861, following Abraham Lincoln’s election to the presidency. He passed away on March 3, 1869, in Kirkwood, Mississippi. McWillie was married twice, first to Nancy Cunningham, who passed away in 1827, and then to Catherina Anderson. He had 15 children. McWillie is buried at Kirkwood Cemetery in Camden, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave; David Sansing, “William McWillie: Twenty-second Governor of Mississippi: 1857-1859,” Mississippi History Now)

gloss.p: Engaging in "illegal activities." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"(The crime of) showing no loyalty to your country, especially by helping its enemies or trying to defeat its government." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The processing of individuals who have committed criminal acts." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The act of formally accusing someone of a serious crime." (Cambridge Dictionary)

"If someone who has committed a crime is pardoned, that person is officially forgiven and their punishment is stopped." (Cambridge Dictionary)"An act of mercy by a person in authority toward someone who has committed a crime, esp. by reducing a punishment." (Cambridge Dictionary)

While the U.S. Constitution grants each chamber some unique power, the House and Senate are equal partners in the legislative process as both chambers are required to enact legislation. U.S. Congress divides legislators into separate committees who write federal or national legislation, and a vast industry of lobbyists also help members write legislation on behalf of corporate and labor interests. Once written, the proposed legislation is introduced to both houses, and if the bill passes both chambers by a majority vote, it is sent to the U.S. President for passage, veto, or pocket-veto, and Congress can overcome the President's veto with a two-thirds majority vote. (Wikipedia)

catDesc.term: Legislation. United States. Congress. General Amnesty Act (1865)

gloss.p: The United States Congress General Amnesty Act (1865) was enacted by President Andrew Johnson on May 29, 1865, giving amnesty (or an official pardon) to former Confederates who participated in the Civil War following an oath of allegiance to the United States and the acceptance of the abolition of enslavement. This act excluded high-ranking military leaders and officials, as well as those who committed war crimes. Johnson believed that amnesty was the surest way to rebuild the nation and the General Amnesty Act was one part of his Reconstruction Plan. This act was welcomed by many Northerners who wanted to move on from the Civil War, but was criticized by many radicals who felt the act was too lenient on Confederate actors and wanted those people excluded from society and punished for their actions in the war. (Wikipedia; National Archives)

catDesc.note:
Categories:
Military Units -- Federal Level: Confederate States Military

gloss.p: The Confederate Army was the military land force of the Confederate States of America during the American Civil War. Known also as the Confederate States Army or Southern Army, it was established by the Provisional Confederate Congress in February 1861 and fell under the authority of Confederate President Jefferson Davis. Modeled after the U.S. Army of the 19th century, the Confederate Army technically fell into two categories: a small regular army of professional officers and soldiers (the Army of the Confederate States of America) and a much larger, temporary force of citizen soldiers intended to exist only for the duration of the war (the Provisional Army of the Confederate States). In reality, the Confederacy’s regular army never fully developed and the overwhelming majority of Confederate soldiers served in the provisional force. The distinction between the two played little role during military operations and all were generally considered to be part of the overall Confederate Army.

As many as 1,000,000 soldiers served in the Confederate Army between 1861 and 1865, although not all at one time. Most were volunteers, however, the Confederate government instituted a conscription (or draft) in April 1862—the first in U.S. or Confederate history—to increase the size of the Confederacy’s military force and encourage voluntary enlistment. The government passed two more conscription acts over the next two years. More than ten percent of the men who served in Confederate ranks were drafted.

Over ninety percent of soldiers in the Confederate Army were native-born white men. Nine percent were foreign-born white men. Several Native American units—particularly from the Cherokee, Creek, and Choctaw tribes—served within the Confederate military, especially in the trans-Mississippi theatre. The Confederate military heavily relied upon the forced labor of enslaved African Americans for building fortifications and carrying out menial tasks, and the Confederate government did not formally allow African Americans (free or slave) to join the army until a last minute desperate measure passed the Confederate Congress in March 1865, only weeks before the end of the war. Only around two hundred enslaved soldiers were organized into service, but they were not sent into combat.

By the time the last Confederate soldiers surrendered to Union forces in June 1865, nearly 100,000 had been killed in combat or succumbed to wounds, more than 160,000 had died of disease, and roughly 30,000 had died in prison camps. (Wikipedia)

catDesc.note:
Categories:
Occupations -- Agricultural & Natural Resource Occupations

gloss.p: "A person or company that arranges to supply materials or workers" in the salt industry. (Cambridge Dictionary)
"Someone whose job is to carry out an official examination of the accounts of a business and to produce a report." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"Someone whose job is to calculate the tax that a person or business has to pay." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"Someone whose job is to collect taxes for the government. The term is often used to refer to the tax authorities." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A person who is in charge of a trial in a court and decides how a person who is guilty of a crime should be punished, or who makes decisions on legal matters." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A public officer who judges local and less important legal cases, and performs marriage ceremonies." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"Someone whose job is to give advice to people about the law and speak for them in court." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A person with special training in the medical field." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A medical doctor, especially one who has general skill and is not a surgeon." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The police force within the armed forces, responsible for dealing with members of the armed forces who break the law." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A member of a group of people who together have the power to make laws." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A person who works in an office, dealing with records or performing general office duties." (Cambridge Dictionary)

catDesc.note:
Categories:
Occupations -- Professional Labor
Occupations -- Transportation & Infrastructure Occupations

gloss.p: "A person who is in charge of a post office." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A company or person that sells cotton using their own name, usually for payment." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A person who delivers mail for the post office." (Cambridge Dictionary)

The Congress of the Confederate States of America was established by Article 1 of the Confederate States Constitution on March 11, 1861 in Montgomery, Alabama. Operating at the national level of the Confederacy, it was the Legislative Branch of the Confederate States government responsible for making and amending laws. A bicameral body, the Confederate States Congress was divided into the upper house (Senate) and the lower house (House of Representatives). The Confederate States Congress concluded Its final session on March 18, 1865. (Avalon Project-Constitution of the Confederate States; March 11, 1861; Wikipedia)

catDesc.note:
Categories:
Organizations -- Educational Organizations
Organizations -- Military Organizations

gloss.p: Military schools are educational programs that incorporate military studies with traditional academic topics. They often emphasize engineering and technical studies. The school lifestyle and environment typically model the military; students are considered cadets, wear uniforms and conduct formation drills, and follow a military-style chain of command. These schools were largely a nineteenth century development in the United States, following the creation of the United States Military Academy at West Point, New York, during Thomas Jefferson’s presidential administration. While that academy, and the United States Naval Academy, founded in 1845, were federal institutions, most military schools were private or state-funded programs. Military service was not required for the graduates of state or private military programs, but alumni from such schools often sought commissions in the military. Additionally, during the Civil War, the Union and the Confederate armies relied heavily upon graduates of state and federal military academies to train and lead the large numbers of civilian soldiers. (Wikipedia)

catDesc.note:
Categories:
Organizations -- Educational Organizations
Organizations -- Military Organizations

gloss.p: Opened in 1802 at West Point, New York, the United States Military Academy is the oldest federal service academy in the United States. Proposed in legislation from Alexander Hamilton, and begun at the direction of President Thomas Jefferson, the academy (often referred to as “West Point”) started with few standards regarding age of cadets or length of study. The War of 1812 prompted revisions within the program and in 1817 the academy’s superintendent Colonel Sylvanus Thayer established a curriculum modeled after the École Polytechnique school in Paris, France, that emphasized technical and engineering instruction. The program was so successful, that it became the model engineering program within the United States during the nineteenth century.

By the 1830s, most commissioned officers in the U.S. Army were West Point graduates. However, distrust among many Americans of a strong national government and aristocracy (as well as jealousy among other aspiring military officers), led to some calls for the elimination of the academy. These calls went unheeded, and the strong performance by West Point graduates during the Mexican War in the late 1840s highlighted the value of the academy to the U.S. military.

The Civil War divided West Point alumni. Some of the most notable academy graduates and staff served the Confederacy, most notably Robert E. Lee. Most of the leading Union generals were also West Point alum, including Ulysses S. Grant, William T. Sherman, and George B. McClellan. Over the course of the war, 294 West Point graduates achieved the rank of general in the Union Army and 151 rose to the rank of general in the Confederate Army. The war also cost the lives of 105 West Point graduates, while 151 were wounded.

Due to political tensions within the U.S. from the Civil War, southern applicants were not admitted to West Point until 1868—three years after the end of the war. The first Black cadet, James Webster Smith, was admitted in 1870, however he faced severe discrimination by other cadets and some staff, leading to altercations, a suspension, and eventually dismissal under controversial circumstances. The first African American cadet to graduate West Point was Henry O. Flipper in 1877.
West Point continues to operate as military service academy training college-aged cadets for the officer corps of the U.S. Army. (Wikipedia)
"A place where trials and other legal cases happen, or the people present in such a place." (Cambridge Dictionary)

catDesc.term: United States--Bureau of Refugees, Freedmen, and Abandoned Lands

gloss.p: Operating at the national level, the Bureau of Refugees, Freedmen, and Abandoned Lands was headquartered in Washington, D. C. Usually referred to as the Freedmen's Bureau, it was formed during early Reconstruction on March 3, 1865 primarily to assist the transition of over four million enslaved people to freedom across the American South. It operated briefly as a U.S. government agency from 1865 to 1872. (Wikipedia)

Operating at the national level, the United States Congress was founded in 1789 as a part of the legislative branch of the nation's federal government. It is comprised of the Senate and the House of Representatives, both of whom are responsible for creating and passing bills and convene at the State's Capitol located in Washington, D.C. Members can be elected to serve repeatedly and must be at least twenty-five years of age for the House of Representatives and at least thirty for the Senate. They must also reside in the state in which they represent and have United States Citizenship for at least seven years for the House of Representatives or nine years for the Senate. (Wikipedia)

Operating at the state level, the Mississippi State Legislature (originally called the "General Assembly") was established by Article 4 of the Mississippi Constitution on November 1, 1890, and serves as the legislative branch of the state government. It is comprised of the House of Representatives and the Senate. The Legislature is responsible for passing new statewide laws and making amendments to the Constitution. (Wikipedia)

A professional scholar, broadly defined, is "a person who is a researcher or has expertise in an academic discipline" who "can also be an academic, who works as a professor, teacher, or researcher at a university" or an independent or public scholar unattached to an institution yet still pursuing a specific subject in an academic field (Wikipedia). As the definition of a scholar is necessarily broad, their qualifications, experiences, and roles in society were likewise diverse.

Scholars in the nineteenth-century U. S. either inside or outside of institutions of higher learning would almost exclusively have been socially and economically elite white males with formal, classical educations and the wealth and consequent time necessary in the nineteenth century to devote oneself to the prolonged study of an academic subject without other streams of income. Many such scholars were responsible for producing and disseminating harmful, pseudoscientific ideas about racial inferiority that undergirded the system of chattel slavery in the antebellum U. S. and later developed into the study and practice of eugenics in the late-nineteenth and early-twentieth centuries.

Scholars also played a crucial role in developing "normal" schools, or teacher training colleges, in the late-nineteenth century. Many professional scholars, themselves with no formal training in how to teach their disciplines, saw after the United States' second industrial revolution the need to provide uniform education to improve the quality of the workforce and thereby saw the equal need to formally train teachers. Scholars therefore, despite not having a formally defined role, played an influential role in shaping popular thought in the nineteenth-century U. S. (SUNY Buffalo).

catDesc.note:
Categories:
Social Identifiers -- Military & Political Status

gloss.p: The prisoner of war experience varied across time and geography during the American Civil War. Both Union and Confederate governments, expecting a short war, did not possess the capabilities of maintaining large prisoner of war populations. Early in the war, prisoners were often exchanged on a one-to-one basis through a parole process and returned to their respective armies. However, the Union Army's enlistment of Black troops in 1862 soured the exchange process and led to the creation of large prison camps in both the North and South.

As the war continued, and battles grew larger and more frequent, the number of prisoners held in these camps quickly exceeded their capacities, leading to overcrowding by 1863. Civil War prison camps, particularly the Andersonville Prison Camp in Georgia, presented some of the most appalling living conditions of the war, which only deteriorated over time. Prisoners of war during the American Civil War faced inadequate food, water, and shelter while living in cramped and deeply unsanitary conditions. Prisoners of war therefore made up a significant portion of deaths during the war, often dying from starvation or sickness. The experiences of prisoners of war differed depending on which camp they were confined to and depending on their race or ethnicity, particularly as the Confederacy in 1863 adopted a policy of executing Black soldiers who surrendered rather than imprisoning them. Even among whites, hostilities over the experiences of battle also led to abuse and violence within the camps, as prisoners sought revenge on vulnerable prisoners.

Ultimately, the prisoner of war experience for those who survived was universally traumatizing and produced one of the most contentious points both during the Civil War and in its commemoration and reconciliation afterword, as the treatment of prisoners of war became a rallying cry for pointing out the cruelties of the enemy for both North and South (National Battlefield Trust; National Park Service).
